questions.question: In 1-persistent CSMA, a station transmits data as soon as it senses that the channel is idle.
Non-persistent CSMA waits for a fixed, constant time interval before attempting to transmit again if the channel is busy.
In p-persistent CSMA, a station sends data with a probability 'p' once the channel is sensed to be idle.
CSMA/CD stands for Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection.
Persistent and non-persistent CSMA protocols generally provide lower performance than the original ALOHA protocol.
Stations utilizing the CSMA/CD protocol abort their current transmissions as soon as a collision is detected.
The CSMA/CD protocol is primarily used to detect and handle collisions in shared-media LANs.
In a CSMA/CD environment, stations should continue transmitting their remaining frame data even after a collision has been detected.
CSMA/CD is a widely implemented protocol within the Medium Access Control (MAC) sublayer of local area networks.
Traditional Ethernet LANs are not based on the CSMA/CD medium access protocol.
Quickly terminating damaged frames during a collision helps save time and bandwidth in CSMA/CD networks.
In the basic bit-map protocol, senders indicate their intent to transmit by setting a bit in a contention slot.
In the Token Ring protocol, the possession of the token determines the sending order of the stations.
In the Token Ring protocol, a station that receives the token must pass it immediately without sending any pending data.
The 'Token' mechanism for medium access can only be implemented on a physical ring topology.
The proliferation of laptop computers and mobile devices significantly increased the demand for wireless local area networking standards.
The IEEE 802 committee is the primary body responsible for standardizing both wired and wireless LAN protocols.
Personal Digital Assistants (PDAs) and cellular phones are typical examples of mobile nodes in a wireless network.
Bandwidth efficiency in a MAC protocol is defined as the ratio of bandwidth used for data transmission to the total available bandwidth.
A well-designed MAC protocol for ad-hoc networks should aim to minimize bandwidth efficiency.
Quality of Service (QoS) support is a fundamental requirement for time-critical network applications.
The design of MAC protocols for ad-hoc networks does not need to consider Quality of Service (QoS).
Synchronization among nodes in an ad-hoc network can be established through the exchange of control packets.
The term 'hidden nodes' in ad-hoc networks refers to stations that are always detectable via standard carrier sensing.
Fading is a wireless phenomenon where the strength of a radio signal diminishes rapidly as the distance from the transmitter increases.
Exposed nodes in ad-hoc networks are stations that are prevented from transmitting because carrier sensing detects an ongoing transmission from another station.
The hidden terminal problem occurs when two stations are unable to detect each other's signals but interfere at a common receiver.
Collision masking occurs in wireless environments when a local signal is strong enough to drown out a remote transmission.
Wireless LANs typically rely on a centralized coordination system for all medium access.
Nodes in most wireless network environments are assumed to be stationary at all times.
Hidden terminals are transmitting nodes that are out of range of each other and cannot sense a conflict.
Exposed terminals are senders who can sense each other's signals but could otherwise transmit safely to different, non-interfering receivers.
Increasing concurrency—allowing multiple safe transmissions to occur at once—generally improves network performance.
The IEEE 802.11 MAC Sublayer Protocol includes specific mechanisms to address the hidden and exposed terminal problems.
Exposed terminals are defined by the fact that their transmissions always collide at their respective intended receivers.
Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance (CSMA/CA) is the standard method for channel access in wireless networks.
Collision avoidance in wireless networks is primarily achieved through a binary exponential back-off mechanism.
Acknowledgement (ACK) packets are used in wireless networks to confirm the successful receipt of a data frame.
The Point Coordination Function (PCF) is a contention-based access method used by all 802.11 stations.
The Point Coordination Function (PCF) provides a contention-free access method for wireless stations.
In PCF mode, the wireless Access Point polls stations according to a predefined list to grant them access to the medium.
The PCF mode in 802.11 is specifically designed to support delay-sensitive applications like voice and video.
The MACA (Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance) protocol uses RTS and CTS frames to solve the hidden and exposed terminal problems.
The Distributed Inter-Frame Space (DIFS) is mathematically calculated as the SIFS plus twice the slot time.
The Short Inter-Frame Space (SIFS) has the highest priority among all inter-frame spaces in 802.11.
The DIFS interval is used to ensure the highest priority service access to the wireless medium.
The PCF Inter-Frame Space (PIFS) has a higher priority (shorter duration) than the SIFS.
The DIFS interval is primarily used for standard asynchronous data services in a wireless LAN.
